title: What will be the FAO Food Price Index for December 2021?
preds: Canola prices as part of the vegetable oil sub index seem to be a major driving force.

The index has been steadily growing since november 2020 with only a slight decrease in june and july and it is at 134.4 for november 2021 (https://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/). The historical (1990-2020) average MoM change november-december has been -0.27% and for the last decade -0.15%. If you take the greatest decrease in the same period of -3.99% (2008) the index could go down to 129.03. For the index to go down to 130.0 the index had to go down -3.27%. The historical probability for this given the MoM changes since 1990 is of 7.13%. Therefore At this point I am assigning a 93% probability for more than 130.0 and 7% for between 120.0 and 130.0.
Food prices have been highest in a decade this year.  Holiday gatherings and supply chain issues will keep food prices elevated.
Reported in 130's in October. Shipping costs, which recently have been declining will keep it historically high

A downward move back below 130 with one month remaining seems unlikely. Watching Omicron variant possible effects nonetheless. https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/world-food-prices-climb-november-stay-10-year-peak-fao-2021-12-02/

The value for Nov was 134.4, up from 132.8 for Oct. I'd give it a <0.5% chance that the value for Dec will be <=130.0. That would require a drop >= 4.4, which is very unlikely given overall inflation, some smaller than expected crop sizes, high demand, increasing fertilizer prices, etc.
134.4 in November. Seems unlikely it makes a large drop in December.
Supply chain issues are impacting food supply and prices as well, along with climate change impacts.
Watching food futures prices next week or so. https://www.forbes.com/sites/mikeosullivan/2021/11/28/what-does-omicron-mean-for-markets/?sh=600a95df1a2b
December is close by and the Index is past 130. I don't believe it go down with the winter in northern hemisphere, supply chain problems and come back from covid (just to name a few).
The Nov report read like the end of days! Mad cow disease, no labor in Malaysia, cereal grain exports down. Only sugar trended down.

Some stabilization in certain foods prices may be possible ahead but futures prices generally point upward, into 2022. The FAO price index has risen in all but two months since 5/2020: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-11-04/global-food-prices-extend-surge-to-pile-on-inflation-pressure https://ahdb.org.uk/cereals-oilseeds-markets https://ahdb.org.uk/news/global-food-prices-rising-but-not-for-meat https://www.reuters.com/article/global-economy-food/world-food-prices-hit-new-10-year-high-in-october-fao-idUKKBN2HP131 https://www.fao.org/fileadmin/templates/worldfood/Reports_and_docs/Food_price_indices_data_nov815.xls

Oct updates are up. Looking increasingly likely that this is above 130:
https://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/

October 2021 value = 133.2. That rules out all bins except 4 and 5.
2 more months to go, and the main signals I see, for cereals and vegetable oils, are pointing strongly up.
Continued to rise in October, up past 133.

Some 'bullish' signals ahead of the next FAO index report (11/4/21): https://www.marketwatch.com/story/ags-week-ahead-tightness-drives-wheat-to-eight-year-high-un-fao-food-prices-index-awaited-271635784479
I probably should wait for Nov 4 report, but I am weighting over 130 stronger now based on wheat price rising.
adjusting for time passed and recent trends. I don't see it going down significantly but there is still room for volatility before the end of theyear
Based on the idea that there will be a lag in price decline from what is expected to be continuing increase in fuel, transportation and wage costs.

For the first part of October, oils have kept going up, palm oil to record levels. Grains are also currently going up. There's a ton of volatility in commodity prices, but current trends favor the index being higher in October. If it is >130.0 for October, then I think that would rule out bin 3. Reducing weight on bin 3.
https://www.agriculture.com/markets/newswire/grains-soybeans-rise-on-tightening-edible-oil-supplies-0 It's also worth noting that the Aug index value was revised upward, from 127.4 to 128.5, in the Sept report. That suggests that any month's value could also be revised later.
https://www.reuters.com/business/world-food-prices-hit-10-year-peak-fao-2021-10-07/
Playing casino here so don't follow me. I'm a rowdy player.

The index climbed 1.5 pts to 130.0 for September, once again driven by cereals and vegetable oils. Sept growth was slower than Aug growth, but it's not clear whether the current increases have peaked yet. The possible outcomes are constrained by time. 3 months left in the forecast. For each bin, the required average change per month in the index for the remaining 4 months:
Bin 1: <-10.0
Bin 2: -10.0 to -6.7
Bin 3: -6.7 to -3.3
Bin 4: -3.3 to +0.0
Bin 5: >0.0 If the index fell as fast as prices rose for a while, that would be a fall of 3.6 points/month. I think that's the lowest reasonable fall we could expect. So, I set bins 1 and 2 to 0 and assign a low probability to bin 3. Beyond that, it could go either way. I'm going to hypothesize that current trends are going to continue a bit further, especially as the growing season is over in a lot of the N Hemisphere. Later edit: the Aug index value was updated to 128.5. That means that the index increased by 5.0 points from July to August.

Fao index at 130.  Veg oils thru the roof at 168. Might be a peak but they will not crash below 130 by december.  Sugar went to 120 which is abiut what i expected and will stay there.  Meat is at  112 and flat but that is still high inflation for meat. Cereals have pptential to continue to climb higher than 132. Put it all together and the index is not closing below 120 for Dec.   The index for next 2 mpnths, i think, will be driven by veg oil and cereal.  If veg oil drops from 168 to 156 and all else is flat then index closes below 130. If veg oils bump up then index is over 130. Cereals also have a potential to inch up if harvests are below expectations.  I feel the other categories are in a stable place as far as production and demand foresights into pricing.

Adjusting, as the FAO food index reached 130.0 in September and the general outlook does not look especially good for prices easing. Rising energy prices apparently are a factor: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-07/food-inflation-heats-up-as-global-prices-return-to-decade-high, https://gro-intelligence.com/insights/articles/food-inflation-worsening-gro-index-signals
Climbed again to 130. Shifting upward as it doesn't seem to be coming down like I had expected.

http://www.fao.org/fileadmin/templates/worldfood/images/home_graph_3_sep841.jpg 120-130 is just 2010 prices, after a much less serious shock to production and labour market. We have been in a dip since then. COVID in poor countries and boom in rich countries would suggest more pressure on food prices.
Still unsure about bin #3 so I'll go with a higher pp for that for now.

re-adjusting for changes over time. it hasn't been below 120 since april. although it did dip in late summer it bounced back up in Aug. I don't see any of the underlying drivers suddenly switching directions so it will likely climb or shift around near where it is now.
127.4 in August. Then I averaged today's values with the linear forecast for December of 136, and derived the standard normal distribution.

No change in forecast. Link to Reuters.com  article on edible oil production woes this year.  https://www.reuters.com/business/rats-drought-labour-shortages-eat-into-global-edible-oil-recovery-2021-09-05/

Using a seasonal naive forecast, we have a prediction between 100 and 110. Using mean and drift we have two predictions between 120 and 130. Using naive forecasting we find a middle balance between 110 and 120.
Guess I was wrong to think it was likely to continue trending down, skewing up now.

Responding to sept report ofnindex at 127.  Adjustment to change from leaning towards below 120 to leaning towards above 130.  I did not expect vegetable oils to rise so strongly but reflecting on covid effectsnin Asia I guess it could have been anticipated.  I thought Brazil would produce more sugar (prior reasoning) but this FAO release indicates Brazil crop was frost damaged.

May adjust forecast further after looking over this latest info.: https://www.reuters.com/article/global-economy-food/world-food-prices-jump-in-aug-cereal-harvest-outlook-cut-fao-idUSR1N2MF024, http://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/

Whoa! The index climbed 3.9 pts to 127.4 for August.
The possible outcomes are becoming constrained by time. For each bin, the required average change per month in the index for the remaining 4 months:
Bin 1: <-6.8
Bin 2: -6.8 to -4.4
Bin 3: -4.3 to -1.9
Bin 4: -1.8 to +0.6
Bin 5: >0.6 If the index fell as fast as prices rose for a while, that would be a fall of 3.6 points/month. I think that's the lowest reasonable fall we could expect, especially given this month's increase. So, I'm zeroing out bins 1 and 2.
Last month, I said that losses and gains below +3/month are more likely and that we seemed to be out of the era of averaging +3.6/month, yet here we are. 
Growth in the index has largely been driven by pandemic dislocations, and those should gradually be resolving over time, but apparently they're not yet.
The crowd seems to expect that the index has more or less reached a peak and that lower values are more likely for Dec than are higher values. Given August events, though, especially poor grain and sugar crop forecasts but also tightening vegetable oil supplies, it's not clear to me that prices have peaked yet. I wonder whether the crowd will agree when it processes the new August data point.
Two consecutive monthly declines with 5 months to go. The biggest risk to this forecast is the Delta variant disrupting supply chains further.

Moving some stuff toward bin 2 just because the average of the last several months is too close to that bin, so if it is regressing to this, then I want to include it. I'm decreasing last bin because months ago I said 125 is my maximum, which even though was broken by the high of 127, we are going down now which just makes the idea of more than 130 seemingly improbable to me.
adjusting for time elapsed, I'm an outlier here but I'm not ready to discount the fact that it's only August and it went down for the first time all year in July, it might continue trending down.
Climate change (fires,floods,droughts) * delta variant spread+global political unrest =higher grain prices!.

Currently at about 123. Keep in mind that the index is not inflation adjusted, it's just straight prices. Keep in mind that this is a question about what is happening with currency as much as it is a question about what is happening with food. So even if the index just keeps up with current inflation it will almost hit 130. However, droughts and famines worldwide are pushing the price of grains higher. https://www.zerohedge.com/commodities/plunging-crop-supplies-send-prices-soaring-and-reignite-food-inflation-fears

FAO price index lowered again in July, but still sounds like there could be some upward pressure from drought and other weather problems, plus some expected supply shortages:  https://farmpolicynews.illinois.edu/2021/08/world-food-prices-fall-in-july-as-the-supply-outlook-for-grain-tightens-in-some-regions/ http://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/

Index fell again in July, to 123, down 1.5 points.
Some factors push some prices up, others cause other prices to fall. The cumulative trend has been down for the past 2 months.
5 months left in forecast. The possibilities are starting to become constrained by time. For each bin, the required average change per month in the index for the remaining 5 months:
Bin 1: <-4.6
Bin 2: -4.6 to -2.6
Bin 3: -2.6 to -0.6
Bin 4: -0.6 to +1.4
Bin 5: >1.4 If the index fell 3.6 points/month (as fast as prices rose for a while), it could fall 18 points, to 105. That's a believable lower limit of possibilities at this point. So, I'm zeroing out bin 1.
Losses and gains below +3/month are more likely; we seem to be out of the era of averaging +3.6/month. Growth in the index was largely driven by pandemic dislocations, and those should gradually be resolving over time, too. Bin 5 looks increasingly less likely to me.
The index fell by an average of 2.4/month for the past 2 months. Continued declines in the range of 2 to 3 points per month should not be ruled out.

Swine herds were killed en masse in the Henan flooding. Droughts in North and South America are cutting yield, and Brazil wheat yield is down 20%. 
https://www.economist.com/business/2021/07/25/as-food-prices-soar-big-agriculture-is-having-a-field-day
Holding forecast steady based on CME futures trending lower this month. The exception is Oats which are way up.
This FAO release offers some perspectives... http://www.fao.org/news/story/en/item/1415065/icode/
Adjusting left due to July dip.
Not a fair question.  Want to know the actual number?  Go back and use the standards used in the 50's, 60's or 70's!

With the June print of 124.6, we have the first decrease after 12 consecutive months of increases... largely powered by a 10% drop in vegetable oil prices (which had nearly doubled in price).  I'm interpreting this as a sign that producers have increased supply in response to the profit opportunities, and vegetable oil prices are unlikely to regain their constantly increasing trend.
Giving equal chances of bins 2 and 3 for the moment, and after June's good news, cautiously optimistic that the index will come down below 120.

It looks like pandemic dislocations are finally starting to resolve. The index went down to 124.6 in the latest report, largely because of a huge, nearly 10% drop in vegetable oil prices, which are finally coming down. Everything else pretty much canceled out. Cereals and dairy went down, by 2.6% and 1.0%, respectively. Meat and sugar went up, by 2.1% and 0.9%, respectively. It's conceivable prices could be even lower by Dec., if cereals crops and the oil production/consumption balance are as good as forecast. I'm still not as sanguine about cereals production forecasts as the futures markets are currently, but realistically, production will probably be very good. And if cereals can keep falling or at least stay stable, so should meat and dairy, to a large extent. So I'm shifting my forecast downward.
6 months left to go. It's not unreasonable to think we could end up back where the price index was around Oct. or Nov. 2020, just over 100.
I am still trying to force myself to spread out my forecasts over more bins. I haven't done that very well on this question so far. Trying to improve.
The index dropped last month, but markets don't move in straight lines. I still think the trend will be a continued increase.

The FAO index fell to 124.6 in June. This confirms my expectation that May was the peak. Complete reversion to the mean would be around 105. I am not sure that will happen by the end of the year. See the links posted by @jayb .

Adjusting forecast somewhat, based upon food price index decline in June (https://www.reuters.com/article/global-economy-food/world-food-prices-fall-in-june-for-first-time-in-a-year-fao-idUSR1N2MF015), plus world cereal forecast (http://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/csdb/en/). But the USDA reportedly expects some food price inflation in months ahead. (Two to three percent:) https://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/18624-food-price-inflation-is-on-the-horizon. Also: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-07-08/global-food-costs-end-year-long-surge-easing-inflation-pressure

Skewing to the right a little bit, but I still think by the end of the year some of the global supply chain issues will have been sorted out and I think we'll see some price declines. Latest report shows FAO declined a bit in June.

There is no chance to be less than 100 for the current tendencies. "A variety of factors are to blame, including a surge in orders from China, fluctuating oil prices, a sliding U.S. dollar, and looming above all: the pandemic, and in some places, reopening," the Post noted. However, they also noted, "Global prices, like the FAO index tracks, and the price that a consumer pays are rarely in sync." And more are starting to mention climate change as a potential long-term factor for the food price outlook. In Nigeria, the Post details the prices for a pot of jollof rice have risen, with the rice component up 10%, the price of a small tin of tomatoes used to make the dish is up 29% and onion prices are up by one-third, according to a Nigerian research firm. In fact, the item notes that the price of onions in Lagos, Nigeria, has doubled in price and there have been heists targeting onions." https://www.dtnpf.com/agriculture/web/ag/columns/washington-insider/article/2021/07/06/global-food-prices-rising 2. all 5 food commodities taken in the index show an increase due to pandemic recovery and expenses from governments for the covid crisis
https://www.enca.com/news/rising-food-prices-deepen-woes-worlds-poorest "
- What is driving the phenomenon? - The global economy is rebounding but inflation is also rising as governments have spent huge sums on stimulus programmes after the pandemic brought economic activity to a standstill last year. China, which the World Bank projects will notch up growth of 8.5 percent in 2021, is gobbling up basic foodstuffs such as oilseed, cereals and meat.
"It really is China which is currently fuelling the surge in food prices," said economist Philippe Chalmin." 3. Harvesting increase is helping dimminish the increased cost
"- How long will it last? -
That is difficult to say. 
For the moment, harvests are projected to be very good.  The US Department of Agriculture is forecasting record crop production for 2021-2022 and also record harvests of Brazilian soybean and American corn. If these materialise, that will help ease the price situation.
" source: https://www.enca.com/news/rising-food-prices-deepen-woes-worlds-poorest https://www.ers.usda.gov/webdocs/outlooks/37731/35047_oce131.pdf?v=2982.4 https://www.agweb.com/news/crops/crop-production/different-calculus-inputs-2022-crop
increased costs for crops make it a balance as well as increased volume https://www.farmforum.net/story/news/columnists/2021/07/01/farmdoc-daily-historical-relationships-suggest-rising-corn-seed-costs-2022/7785555002/

https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-hog-prices-sink-as-china-rebuilds-herd-11624959001
This will relieve pressure on corn and soybeans as well.
Rethinking. We're not *that* far above 120 right now, and there's a lot of time between now and December.

Previous two peaks saw reversion the the mean within 8 months.
Based on recent commodity prices I believe May will be the peak month.

Commodity prices started to retreat from their highs in recent weeks.  Reversion to the mean would be around 100. I believe as bottlenecks in the supply chain are relieved prices will return to normal slowly.

I haven't looked closely at the construction of the FAO food price index, but the major constituents are: cereals, vegetable oils, dairy, meat, and sugar. Looking at futures around Nov 2021 - Jan 2022, it's a bit of a mixed bag.
Wheat is up from today, as is sugar and cattle.
But corn and soybean oil are down.  https://futures.tradingcharts.com/marketquotes/ZW.html
https://futures.tradingcharts.com/marketquotes/SB.html
https://futures.tradingcharts.com/marketquotes/GF.html
https://futures.tradingcharts.com/marketquotes/ZC.html
https://futures.tradingcharts.com/marketquotes/ZL.html Not familiar with farming or food in general, so I'm not sure what kinds of upside or downside surprises might happen or their likelihood of happening. Will follow current index values + futures closely, with a bit of flattening of probabilities and mixing with crowd forecast due to lack of knowledge.
Commodities can be so volatile, though.

Changing from 0/0/17/60/23. Index is at 127.  It will rise over 130 as expected. Oil is an input to food production so that is a base support for higher prices.  Sugar is rising due to conditions in Brazil, but thus rise can turnaround and remove pressure.  US wheat production looks like it may be stronger then people think, another pressure relief.  China demand may back off if COVID continues there, which is another pressure relief. So in conclusion, oil supports index over 120. But production increases and demand reduction may allow for index to settle below 130. Of course, index could close over 130 December. Still keeping 5 percent for below 120 in case the Echo Variant of Covid destroys American Demand (aka I don't know stuff happens)
Drought.  Strong China demand.  Range of 127-137
Increasing the probability of >130 given the latest FAO report for May. (1) http://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/

Hard to see the index falling below 110 by the end of the year from where we stand now, especially with all the dislocations of the pandemic.
Value of the index was 127.1 in May. It's hard to picture it falling below 120 by the end of the year, but that's more possible.
I don't foresee many pressures letting up by the end of the year, so I will weight the highest category a little stronger than before. 
(And once again, by sheer accident, I end up pretty close to the crowd forecast.)
Trend will skyrocket past 130. But when food prices fall, they fall off a cliff.

New FAO numbers published today, and the index increased to 127.1 from 121.3 last month. Biggest month-over-month increase in a decade. 'Twelfth consecutive monthly rise' which leads me to believe it will continue increasing. 
http://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/

Excerpt: "The FAO Food Price Index (FFPI) averaged 127.1 points in May 2021, 5.8 points (4.8 percent) higher than in April and as much as 36.1 points (39.7 percent) above the same period last year. The May increase represented the biggest month-on-month gain since October 2010. It also marked the twelfth consecutive monthly rise in the value of the FFPI to its highest value since September 2011..." Source: http://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/ Hard for me to see prices significantly reversing soon. Excerpt: "Strong demand from China, stockpiling of grains by governments since the outbreak of Covid-19 and dry weather in key exporting countries have all contributed to rising prices of agricultural products." Source: https://www.ft.com/content/007bd0a0-f149-427d-937c-ec5b0ef4374d  https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/agricultural/grain-and-oilseed/rough-rice.html#

If it keeps rising, I don't see more than 130; maybe 125 ballpark. Best guess is 120–123. If it keeps decreasing, maybe 117. Monitor the plateauing trend. Trim off 100 zone if decline is not drastic or if an increase continues over next couple months. Update: I think I was forecasting for the next month and not December. Oops.
Previous forecast was a wrong interpretation of the data.
This forecast was a wrong interpretation of the data.

FAO Food Price upated on 06MAY21 to 120.9, a 2.0 point rise from the prior month. Unbroken string of increases since the onset of COVID averaging ~2.7 point increase each month which would indicate a linear forecast of 144 (a number which I don't think has ever been reached though).
http://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/

New report out today: 120.9 for April, 2021. Convex down in the data since Dec, 2020, but still a growth trend overall since May, 2020. Looks like growth in the index might be slowing down, but it's hard to say what's going on (for me, at least). This month's index value was higher because all of the component indices went up a little bit; oils were up only 1.8% in the past month. I think it's likely that dairy and sugar will fall a bit over the next few months. I think there's some risk that cereals will go up, though, if expected bumper crops don't materialize because of unexpected weather events, etc. Potential effects of the pandemic on production, consumption, exports and imports in South Asia and South America also adds uncertainty. I had previously weighted the highest category fairly high; I'm going to increase the weightings of lower categories for now. (I find myself in surprising agreement with the current consensus!) Just for fun, R^2 for a few different fits to data from May, 2020 onward, and corresponding predictions for the index for Dec. 21:
Linear: 0.979, 140
Exponential: 0.986, 157
Polynomial (2nd degree): 0.99, 162
Polynomial (3rd degree): 0.997, 98
Of course, these fits are largely meaningless, but they show us a range of possibilities. (We could equally well fit a 2nd degree polynomial to concave down data from 12/20 onward and get a prediction of 104 with R^2 = 0.999.)

Excerpt: "The FAO Food Price Index (FFPI) averaged 120.9 points in April 2021, 2.0 points (1.7 percent) higher than in March and as much as 28.4 points (30.8 percent) above the same period last year. The increase marked the eleventh consecutive monthly rise in the value of the FFPI to its highest level since May 2014. The April rise was led by strong increases in the prices of sugar, followed by oils, meat, dairy and cereals." 5/6/21 source: http://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/ A quick estimate: If the index continues its rise at 'just' one percent per month between the (upcoming) May and December '21 reports (inclusive) the FFPI value would be around 130.9 as of Dec. '21.
Reached 118 already and it's only March. India lockdown will just exacerbate food production and distribution pressures. Rising transportation costs make it likely the index will go higher.

March was 118.5 10th straight month of rising index. http://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/
grain prices and futures are really high which means people think prices are going to go even higher. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-04-26/crop-prices-on-a-roll-as-soybeans-rocket-to-highest-since-2013?srnd=premium&sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew
Adjusting my forecast up a bit. I still think it is possible that the index goes down, it is really early in the growing season in the northern hemisphere so fears of drought may or may not come to fruition.

There are too many moving parts so . A simple look at the historical chart says it is mean reverting (the last 5 year avg (since 2015 is 96). On the other hand during arab spring the index went above 130 for 9 months. So hedging my bets, will narrow down as we approach closer to the end date.

http://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/ The central tendency is rising from a high teens value.   Products subject to high-income elasticity effects in developing economies- like oils and proteins  - get pressured in both spot and futures markets during the expected post-COVID vaccination boom. Harvest effects from continuing long-term drought cycles could pressure futures. Central bank inflation damping efforts are in a dovish cycle, and the non-core types for commodities like food would get spillover of overshoot

Update. The index rose again for March, led by an 8% increase in vegetable oil prices, followed by dairy at 4% and meat at 2%. Sugar prices fell by 4%, and cereals fell by 2%. Bumper cereal crops are expected in 2021, but demand for cereals is expected to overtake production, thanks to increasing feed use. "World cereal stocks at the end of 2021 are forecast to decline by 1.7 percent from their opening levels to 808 million tonnes. Combined with the utilization forecasts, the global cereal stock-to-use ratio for 2020/21 is foreseen to dip to a seven-year low of 28.4 percent."
https://reliefweb.int/report/world/global-food-prices-rise-10th-month-row How will trends change as the year unfolds? I suspect demand for vegetable oils will remain high. I suspect that cereal prices will rise at some point; perhaps crops will not fare as well as expected, and reduced stocks will likely drive up prices as well. I bet meat prices will be sustained or increased in part by continuing increases in demand in China, driven by high growth rates for the Chinese economy as a whole. Sugar prices could fall a bit further if India ends up exporting a lot of sugar. I suspect dairy prices will decline a bit over the coming year as short-term and seasonal constraints ease. Overall, I can picture vegetable oils, cereals, and possibly meat prices driving up the index further, and dairy and sugar potentially pulling it down a bit, with a net result of an additional increase of maybe 10% to 30% by the end of the year, corresponding to index values of 129 to 153. But, there's a lot of uncertainty. Another reality check from a different angle: FPI increased by 2.2% from Feb. to March, and 2.8% from Jan. to Feb. So let's say an average of 2.5%/month. If this trend continues unabated, the FPI for Dec. would be in the ballpark of 118*(1.025)^9 = ~147, corresponding to a 25% increase over March. Hey @SE_Meyer, why do you think the index is likely to fall? What forces do you see at work?

The FAO Food Price Index (FFPI) averaged 118.5 points in March 2021, 2.4 points (2.1 percent) higher than in February. The increase marked the tenth consecutive monthly rise in the value of the FFPI to its highest level since June 2014.
The FAO Cereal Price Index averaged 123.6 points in March, down 2.2 points (1.7 percent) from February, ending the eight-month rising trend, but still 25.9 points (26.5 percent) above its March 2020 level. Among major cereals, wheat export prices declined the most in March, falling 2.4 percent, however, they remained 19.5 percent higher than in the same month last year. 
 The FAO Dairy Price Index averaged 117.4 points in March, up 4.4 points (3.9 percent) from February, rising for the tenth consecutive month and lifting the index to nearly 16 percent above its value in the corresponding month last year. 
The FAO Meat Price Index* averaged 98.9 points in March, up 2.2 points (2.3 percent) from February, continuing the upward trend for the sixth consecutive month, but still stood slightly (0.5 percent) below its value a year ago. Poultry and pig meat quotations increased, underpinned by a fast pace of imports by Asian countries, mainly China. A surge in internal sales in Europe in preparation for the Easter celebrations also supported pig meat prices.
The FAO Sugar Price Index averaged 96.2 points in March, down 4 points (4.0 percent) from February, marking the first decline after sharp increases registered in the previous two months. Sugar quotations remained, however, more than 30 percent above their levels in the corresponding period of last year, underpinned by concerns over tight global supplies in 2020/21.

If the FAO index averages a one percent monthly increase from April through December 2021 (nine months) it would end up just under 130. The most recent monthly increase (March 2021) was 2.1 percent and since December 2020 the index's monthly increase is averaging around 3 percent, with the last two months somewhat lower.  "Positive cereal crop prospects in 2021" may help ease price increases somewhat going forward: https://reliefweb.int/report/world/global-food-prices-rise-10th-month-row, https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-04-08/global-food-costs-keep-climbing-in-threat-to-consumer-wallets

Comment: It is my first attempt to see how it works, I have to do some more research on the topic to improve prediction. Rationale: the pandemic, abnormal weather events for the season, some political and economic instability in countries that produce food, slow vaccination campaigns, no new technologies to increase production to balance a weather related disruption (that I know of), governments will try to attenuate the problem, investment in automation is possible and could keep the index from getting out of control (international cooperation could be necessary though).

Looking at historical data, 100-110 and 110-120 seem most likely bets given where it is now.  My general sense of the underlying fundamentals, including pandemic disruptions, inflationary pressures due to government spending, and continued global political turmoil, it does seem there are significant upward pressures.  The index spends very little time over 130, so, this far out, I see that as unlikely on the date picked, but maybe not unlikely at some point in the next year.

The index is in the 110 to 120 territory but that's after 9-10 months of continuous increase. The prices of ag commodities are already relatively high and I see no reason for them to go higher. Reduced supply is already baked into the expectations and my projection is that demand will rather stagnate or fall as the pandemic continues in Africa and other LMICs, affecting purchasing power. I would not be surprised about a steep fall in food prices.

The FAO Food Price Index averaged 116.0 in February, 2021 and has risen for the past 9 months, by an average of about 3.6 points per month, and 2.8 points from Jan. to Feb. 2021. Some portion of this meteoric rise can be attributed to pandemic disruptions, but a wide range of unrelated and correlated factors are contributing significantly as well, from weather to speculative investment to politics. I don't see an end in 2021 to the forces propelling the index upward, but this index can be quite volatile.

The data is showing 116.0 for February 2021.
An increase of 2.8 points or (2.4 percent higher than January 2021 or 9 months of increase. 
2/2 I will go out on a limb and say the increase will continue as stimulus funds are driving the price index around the world.

Changed from 0/ 8/ 27/ 42/ 23  because i am considering what drives a rise in food prices. Food is globally traded so the valje of the dollar is significant.  So as dollars flood the system the dollar becomes weaker and more dollars needed to buy the same amount of food.  This assumes no change in supply.  If supply increased as dollar weakened then the two could offset one another but that depends on rates of change.  I believe drought in US and Europe will reduce supply of wheat and grains.  Finally there is a restriction in available containers used to ship certain food products which will increase food prices.  So i decided to be more bullish.

Looking at the past data, it has been below 100 for 12 of the last 17 years including last year.
last year it was below 100 for 8 months. so there is a decent chance that it follows that pattern and goes back down. Especially since governments will want to take what measures they can do drive food prices back down. However it is higher now than it has been since 2014 which was at the tail end of a run of years over 100, and we're starting this year at 116 with a trend of rising a point or two per month. if it continued rising at that rate we could be over 130 by December.   I'm guessing that it will stay high for awhile so December will be close to what we have now with some possibility of higher or lower. Since governments will try to slow or reverse the trend so its more likely to be lower than higher. will adjust my forecast as we see what actually happens.

The index currently sits as 116.0 for February, and has been trending up since May of last year. While vaccinations are increasing in many countries, so supply disruptions and fiscal stimulus will likely start moving in the opposite direction as they have been by December, large swaths of the world will still be unvaccinated. On the whole, I expect government borrowing to continue, meaning debasement of currency, and hence continued nominal increases (if not real increases, which has also been the case since COVID, due to supply shortages) in food prices compared to today.

As per FAO, Feb Index is 116.0, which is continuously increasing for 9 months now, propelled mainly be the sub-indices of vegetable oil and sugar. Record production forecasts of cereals will contain the price rise, however, vegetable oil needs to be given close attention.
Hence, the chances are that index will keep rising may be at a slower rate (1-2%). Hence the index may fall in the range 120-130.

A simple probability table based on the diff of current value over the interval until question close using past values. In other words, ladies and gents, it's best to hedge your bets and not think the fourth highest option is >50% because of your beliefs about inflation. FAO Food Prices for 2021-12-01 forecast:
====================================================
Prob. | Brier | Bins 
====================================================
0.087 | 1.110 | Bin 1 - <100
0.187 | 0.910 | Bin 2 - 100 to <=110
0.440 | 0.404 | Bin 3 - 110+ to <120
0.200 | 0.884 | Bin 4 - 120 to <=130
0.087 | 1.110 | Bin 5 - 130+
====================================================
Number of observations: 150 Note: Brier scores assume 5 bins and the line it is on is correct.
It also is not using the "ordered categorical scoring rule", which
is why the scores seem brutal.

There seems to have been crop failures in some regions of the world, in some places maybe driven by drought and heat waves, in other places, probably in Eastern Africa, mostly driven by mass locust appearance.
This is what the onset of the current price rally in September 2020, and the sharp price increase in mainly Cereals and Vegetable oils suggest. These two likely also have the heaviest weight in the basket of five subsegments. All other segments have increased only moderately and are still below the average of 116.0 as of Feb 2021.
Going back in history, 2008/09 and 2011/12 appear to be an apt comparison to 2020/21, and in both cases, one year of sharp price increases, driven mainly by cereals and vegetable oils, was followed by a year in which the FFPI dropped either sharply (2009) or moderately (2012). While Sugar was a third sector with drastic price changes in both of these cases, it does not play a role this year obviously, as world supply for export from the Northern hemisphere could be sufficient.
My guess is prices will continue to rise in H12021, before they drop moderately in H22021 with the harvest in the Northern hemispere (e.g. wheat production in Russia largely determines the world export price for wheat) towards the end of the year.
Forecast: above, but near 100.0, maybe 102.5

The Feb. 2021 most recently reported FAO Food Price index value was 116.0, the highest number since 2015. The index value has now increased 16.7 percent since Feb. 2020. (http://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/) Analysis I've read thus far is more or less in-line with this excerpt:  "...Rabobank senior commodity analyst Charles Clack said the higher prices will be around for some time to come. "We don't expect the US dollar to strengthen any time soon [and] we expect La Niña will continue to cause drier conditions in the northern hemisphere while global demand will stay strong," he said." (https://www.abc.net.au/news/rural/2021-03-10/food-prices-around-the-world-rising/13234746) A quick over-simplified projection (for starters for this question) would be to take the December 2020 index number of 108.5 and multiply it by 1.167 to get a possible Dec. '21 estimated value of about 126.6. That projected number would be the highest since 2011 (a/k/a the 'Arab Spring' year). (https://slate.com/technology/2014/04/food-riots-and-revolution-grain-prices-predict-political-instability.html) For now I'll center a first forecast around the rough estimate above, in part because of this additional projected factor: "Sharp drops in world cereal stocks foreseen", (http://www.fao.org/news/story/en/item/1372486/icode/), although a large wheat output is also forecast (a possible mitigating factor): (https://www.axios.com/global-food-prices-coronavirus-protests-9d81f4c6-7665-4aa5-9250-a5b670efdb30.html)

According to the FAO link it's currently at 116 and rising, prior to the pandemic really kicking off in February 2020 it had fallen to the mid 90s. I'm assuming the recent rise is mostly pandemic related. Also I think the rest of the world is a ways off from being out of the woods as far as the pandemic goes, even though the US and other rich countries look like they should be seeing better days this summer due to vaccinations. So I think there's a good chance the index continues to rise through 2021. However, the US sounds like it's one of the larger food producers, so if the US can get its economy back to a relative normal this summer maybe it can bring food prices back down a bit which might keep the FAO index from rising so much. But an increase in inflation could also cause prices to rise more. Based on those considerations I'm putting the most weight on it increasing into the 120s or higher, though setting a decent amount of weight on it staying about the same or coming back down.

This is a monetary issue much more than a supply issue. You just can't keep printing money and not expect the dollar to fall. This is not transitory.
